text.Prompt:
From 2017, Bitcoin And Other Digital Currency Will No Longer Be Taxed Twice In Australia

As part of its push to foster innovation and fintech startup businesses in Australia, the government's 2017 Federal Budget will cut the GST for purchases of digital currency, allowing Bitcoin and online games' in-game money to be treated just like plain Australian dollars for tax purposes.

At the moment, anyone purchasing a digital currency in Australia is technically liable for GST expenses on that purchase. From 1 July 2017, though, the government is exempting purchases of digital currency from Australia's 10 per cent Goods and Services tax. The announcement was made in March of last year, and in 2014 the ATO said small-scale traders — below $10,000 — would not be charged GST on their transactions.

GST still applies when exchanging those digital currencies for other goods and services that are themselves subject to the GST, of course. The government confirmed the removal of GST on digital currencies in its innovation and fintech fact sheet.

In the government's budget measures paper, removing GST on Bitcoin was called out as being useful while not costing the Federal Government any significant revenue: "Removing double taxation on digital currencies will remove an obstacle for the financial Technology (fintech) sector to grow in Australia. This measure is estimated to have a small but unquantifiable decrease in GST collections and associated payments to the States and Territories over the forward estimates period."

Startups aren't happy with the work the government has done, though. CEO of startup advocacy group StartupAUS Alex McCauley: "There clearly isn't a focus on startups or innovation in this budget. That will certainly cause some frustration, because the Government has done a lot to build expectations that it is committed to making Australia one of the best countries in the world for innovators. It still has a lot of work to do to deliver on that commitment.

From the budget's fintech fact sheet:

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: Australia's government has announced plans to cut the 10% Goods and Services Tax (GST) for digital currency purchases, following in the footsteps of New Zealand. The Australian Federal Budget will remove the tax from digital currency transactions starting from 1 July 2017, with the government estimating the move will cost it no significant revenue. The announcement comes after the ATO confirmed that small-scale traders, below $10,000, would not be charged the tax on their transactions. The move has been widely praised by the tech community, with Alex McCauley, CEO of the Australian Startup Advocacy Group, stating: "There clearly isn't a focus on startups or innovation in this budget. That will certainly cause some frustration, because the Government has done a lot to build expectations that it is committed to making Australia one of the best countries in the world for innovators. It still has a lot of work to do to deliver on that commitment."
text.Response B: The Australian government's 2017 federal budget will remove the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from digital currency purchases, so bitcoin and other digital currencies will be treated as if they were dollars. From 1 July, digital currency purchases will no longer be eligible for the 10% GST and this change should help the digital fintech sector grow further in Australia. The tax still applies when exchanging digital currencies for goods and services.

In the past, however, Pixel and Nexus devices didn't have the ability to run Samsung's browser, so this expansion to non-Samsung hardware may put a little more pressure on Google.

A study released exactly one year ago reported 25 percent of mobile users had some form of ad blocking installed on their device, and projected a rise to 80 percent by the end of 2017. Shortly after iOS 9 released, The New York Times conducted its own tests and corroborated the proposed benefits of ad blocking — namely, faster load times, significantly decreased data usage, and even a modest gain in battery life.

There's also CloseBy, a feature that recommends websites and information based on the user's location.

ESPN is upping its game in China.

The Disney (DISNEY) unit is teaming up with tech giant Tencent to cover sports games in China -- with Mandarin-language commentary -- according to a joint statement Wednesday. The 2016 NBA playoffs in April will be the first games to feature ESPN analysis in Chinese on Tencent's digital platforms.

Tencent (TCEHY) has also acquired the digital rights to stream "March Madness," a popular U.S. college basketball tournament, and will publish ESPN sports stories in Chinese online.

Basketball is extremely popular in China where NBA games are carried by state broadcaster CCTV and other stations. By working with Tencent, ESPN is trying to reach new audiences.

The deal benefits both sides: ESPN is looking abroad to stem cable subscriber losses back home, while Tencent is engaged in a mad scramble for content in China.

Related: LeBron shoots for billionaire status

It's no surprise rival tech firms are racing to get a bigger slice of China's $180 billion entertainment and media market, which is growing 10% a year on average, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers.

The ESPN-Tencent agreement is the latest in a string of distribution deals in China.

Tencent struck an agreement in 2014 to distribute Sony's music library, including artists such as Beyonce, online in China. The company even inked deals with National Geographic and YG Entertainment, the Korean pop label that backs singer Psy of "Gangnam Style" fame.

Also in 2014, competitor Alibaba (BABA) took a majority stake in a film production company, renaming it Alibaba Pictures.

Related: Disney's $5 billion Chinese theme park set to open

It has also invested vast sums in Internet television firm Youku Tudou (YOKU) and a local music service provider. In September, Alibaba launched TBO, it's own Netflix-style video streaming service.

ESPN remains Disney's most profitable channel, but it has lost millions of subscribers as customers switch to smaller cable packages. The channel has suffered mass layoffs, and is seeking new ways to bring in revenue.

While it's still focused on its traditional core market in North America, ESPN has been branching out to get its content in in front of consumers in other countries.

Generate a summary:

ESPN will distribute content across Tencent's online portals including QQ Sports and WeChat. Tencent will pay ESPN for exclusive Mandarin-language content that will provide coverage and analysis of basketball and international football, two popular sports in China. Additional sports are expected to be added over the course of the agreement. ESPN is looking abroad for new ways to bring in revenue while Tencent is engaged in a scramble for quality content in China. According to PricewaterhouseCoopers, China's entertainment and media market is worth $180bn and is growing on average 10% per year.
text.Response B: IBM is launching a tool for maths teachers powered by artificial intelligence (AI) to help them with targeted resources for students. text.Prompt:
Dive Brief:

A K-12 chief information officer's time used to be spent primarily on IT tasks, but amid ed tech's increasing prevalence and a push for data-driven decision-making, CIOs have had to adapt and spend more time helping educators and administrators track and assess data.

District Administration reports CIOs serve as data interpreters and visionaries, facilitating understanding between technology departments and academic/operational branches of their districts and developing a long-term plan about where data fits into the district's strategic goals.

CIOs also fulfill a training role, helping educators without data backgrounds gain insights from analytics, and they break down silos by connecting people from various departments with data to meet continuous improvement goals.

Dive Insight:

There is much talk about how schools haven't changed at all in centuries, but the fact is school and district leaders have had a lot to adapt to in recent years. The digital age has brought a range of new technologies into schools, and that has provided new opportunities for data collection and analysis. Schools are behind other sectors in embracing this potential, however.

A recent report from public policy think tank the Center for Data Innovation urged federal and state policymakers to incentivize faster adoption in schools and districts. Beyond encouraging administrators to use data to improve their operations and instructional practices, the Center for Data Innovation wants schools to get data into the hands of students and parents, giving them more agency over the learning process.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: The role of a K-12 chief information officer has evolved over time as ed tech and data analytics have become more prevalent in K-12 institutions. CIOs now spend less time on IT tasks and more time helping educators and administrators track and assess data to inform their decision-making. CIOs serve as data interpreters and visionaries, facilitating understanding between technology departments and academic/operational branches of their districts and developing a long-term plan about where data fits into the district's strategic goals. They also help educators without a data background gain insights from analytics and connect people from various departments with data to meet continuous improvement goals.
text.Response B:
The demand for greater transparency and accountability within K-12 has pushed educators to prioritize data-driven decision-making. As a result, the role of the CIO has evolved to include data interpreter and visionary, helping to facilitate understanding between technology departments and academic/operational branches of districts. A key responsibility for the CIO is to break down silos and connect people from various departments with data to meet continuous improvement goals.

To fulfill this new role, the CIO must have a deep understanding of how data is collected and analyzed, and an even deeper understanding of how to translate it into actionable insights for stakeholders. This requires the CIO to work closely with other district leaders to develop a long-term plan for how data can be integrated into the district's strategic goals.

Source:

District Administration

text.Prompt:
mHealth App Detects Postpartum Depression

Approximately one in nine women has symptoms of postpartum depression (PPD) after having a baby, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Postpartum depression (PPD) is more intense and a greater potential risk for the mother and newborn than the "baby blues," the common term for short-term worry, sadness, and tiredness many women experience post delivery. While treatable, postpartum depression often escapes diagnosis. Differentiating between baby blues and postpartum depression in the busy days immediately following birth poses a challenge.

Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital's Ammon-Pinizzotto Center for Women's Mental Health developed an iPhone mHealth app to screen for PPD. The MGH Perinatal Depression Scale (MGHPDS) includes questionnaires about mood, sleep, anxiety, and stress. The app, which blends existing PPD screening tools, serves a purpose beyond pre-diagnosis. Women who use the app can choose to share their responses with the researchers to assist in the development of an "even shorter scale with greater specificity than what is currently available," says Lee S. Cohen, MD, director of the Ammon-Pinizzotto Center and professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School.

The free mHealth app, available now on the iPhone App Store, will launch an Android version later in 2017. The Mass General researchers plan to release version 2.0 during the second half of 2018. Apps such as these have the potential to give individual patients more control and easier access to potentially helpful information and services.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: A new app, developed by researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital's Ammon-Pinizzotto Center for Women's Mental Health, can identify symptoms of postpartum depression in a user's first few weeks after birth, with the ability to share responses with researchers to assist in the development of an "even shorter scale with greater specificity than what is currently available." The free app, available on the iPhone App Store, will be made available to Android users later this year, with plans to release version 2.0 in the second half of 2018.
text.Response B: An iPhone app developed by researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital can screen for postpartum depression.  The app, which is called the MGH Perinatal Depression Scale, or MGHPDS, is available for free on the iPhone App Store and blends existing postpartum depression screening tools.  The researchers plan to release a new version of the app in the second half of 2018, and they also plan to release an Android version of the app later in 2017.  PPD affects approximately one in nine women, but the app can help distinguish between PPD and the baby blues.  Baby blues is a common term for the short-term worry, sadness, and tiredness that many women experience after giving birth, but postpartum depression is more intense and poses a greater risk to the mother and newborn.  The app can also collect data from users to help researchers develop an even shorter screening tool with greater specificity than what is currently available.

text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: Moderna, Inc.'s revenues from its COVID-19 vaccines have begun an anticipated decline, reflecting the broader trend in drugs and vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 as the pandemic begins to wind down, and it is forecasting a steep drop in coronavirus vaccine sales in 2023. But the messenger RNA-focused biotech's fourth quarter and full year 2022 earnings also hint that the post-pandemic future that it has been building toward is taking shape as newer mRNA-based products inch closer to the market, particularly in infectious diseases like respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and oncology.

Moderna announced its earnings on 23 February, reporting fourth quarter revenues of $5.1bn and full year revenues of $19.3bn, nearly all of which - $4.9bn and $18.4bn, respectively - came from global sales of Spikevax.

But the firm is keen to establish itself as a multi-product company. "The company continues to expand at a rapid pace," CEO Stephane Bancel told Moderna's same-day earnings call. "We now have three commercial COVID-19 vaccine products. We have four programs in Phase III."

He added that the company is on track to expand its commercial portfolio "very soon" and overall has 48 programs underway.

"Our $18bn of cash balance at the end of the year is enabling us to scale across research, clinical development, manufacturing, commercial and G&A," he said.

Bigger Drop In Pandemic Sales To Come

Along with other drug makers that have experienced record revenues and profits from COVID-19 vaccines and drugs - such as Pfizer Inc., Merck & Co., Inc. and Gilead Sciences, Inc. - Moderna has begun to see its sales take a downward trajectory. For the fourth quarter, the sales figure for Spikevax and related bivalent vaccines represented a 30% decrease from the comparable period in 2021, while for the full year it represented only a 4% increase. Profit for the fourth quarter was $1.5bn, and for the full year it was $8.4bn, representing decreases of 70% and 31%, respectively.

For the full year of 2023, Moderna expects Spikevax to have sales contracted for delivery of $5bn.

Moderna's experience is analogous to those of other companies that have relied on pandemic windfalls. In its fourth quarter and full year 2022 earnings, Gilead reported a 26.3% decline in sales of its antiviral Veklury (remdesivir) owing to lower rates of infection and hospitalization. (Also see "Gilead CAR-T Joins Billion-Dollar Club As Biktarvy Sales Cross $10bn Mark" - Scrip, 2 Feb, 2023.) Pfizer also said in its earnings that it expects sales of Comirnaty, the SARS-CoV-2 vaccine it markets with BioNTech SE, to decline along with those of its antiviral treatment Paxlovid (nirmatrelvir/ritonavir). (Also see "From Hallelujah To Headwind: Pfizer's COVID-19 Franchise Hits The Downturn" - Scrip, 31 Jan, 2023.) Merck issued a similar forecast for its COVID-19 drug, Lagevrio (molnupiravir). (Also see "Merck & Co. Remains 'Very Confident' In TIGIT" - Scrip, 2 Feb, 2023.)

Company's Post-Pandemic Future Starts To Take Shape

Early on, Moderna moved to invest its revenues in pumping up its R&D, and while Bancel pointed to the dozens of programs it now has across a wide variety of disease states, the earnings report showed a diversified commercial-stage biotech company taking shape.

Its likely first commercial product after its COVID-19 vaccines will be another vaccine against another respiratory infection, mRNA-1345 for RSV in older adults, for which Moderna plans regulatory filings in the first half of 2023.

"The topline results we've seen are incredibly encouraging, and we're grateful to the [US Food and Drug Administration] for [breakthrough therapy designation] for mRNA-1345, which further emphasizes the significant health impact of RSV in older adults and the high unmet need," Moderna president Stephen Hoge told the 23 February call.

Phase III results announced in January for mRNA-1345 showed that the vaccine had 83.7% efficacy against RSV lower respiratory tract disease, indicating a rate of efficacy slightly higher than the 82.6% efficacy of GSK plc's vaccine and significantly more than the 66.7% of Pfizer's competitor. However, those were only topline data that make direct comparisons challenging. (Also see "Phase III Results Show Moderna Could Challenge In Blockbuster RSV Vaccine Market" - Scrip, 18 Jan, 2023.)

Moderna expects a Phase III interim efficacy analysis for mRNA-1010, its flu vaccine, to undergo data safety monitoring board review before the end of the first quarter.

But the company is making progress outside of respiratory infections as well, particularly in oncology.

On 22 February, the FDA granted breakthrough therapy designation to mRNA-4157/V940, the mRNA cancer vaccine that Moderna is developing for melanoma under partnership with Merck and combining with the PD-1 inhibitor Keytruda (pembrolizumab) in the Phase IIb KEYNOTE-942/mRNA-4157-P201 trial. Data from the trial announced in December showing a 44% lower risk of recurrence or death for combination compared with Keytruda alone led to the breakthrough designation. (Also see "Moderna Chalks Up Industry Milestone With mRNA Cancer Vaccine Efficacy Success" - Scrip, 14 Dec, 2022.)

Hoge noted on the call that it was the first demonstration of efficacy for an investigational mRNA-based cancer treatment in a randomized trial, and Moderna and Merck plan to start "multiple late-stage confirmatory studies" in 2023, starting in melanoma and then moving to non-small cell lung cancer.

"We are planning to explore additional indications for 4157, where we believe there's a strong biologic rationale for immune-stimulating approaches," he said. "These include early-stage and metastatic settings and will include indications where Keytruda is not yet approved."
Summary: The company reported a fourth quarter decline in SARS-CoV-2 vaccine sales but guided for sales of $10bn in 2023. It is looking ahead to filing for approval of its RSV vaccine.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
text.Response A: Yes
text.Response B: The document discusses the decline in SARS-CoV-2 vaccine sales for Moderna but also mentions the upcoming approval filing for its RSV vaccine. It also highlights the company's investment in R&D and diversification into other disease areas. The summary accurately reflects the information provided in the document.

text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: The Biden administration unveiled new details Thursday of how it will seek to get the most bang for the billions it has at its disposal to spur the semiconductor sector in the U.S.

The centerpiece of the plans, which Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo laid out during a speech, is the creation of at least two semiconductor manufacturing and research hubs in the U.S. These sites--she hopes--will create new U.S. manufacturing and research capabilities and supply chains that will generate momentum for the sector even after the government money runs out.

"I want to talk about the vision," Raimondo began her speech, comparing the effort to major moments in U.S. history. "The CHIPS and Science Act presents us with an opportunity to make investments that are similarly consequential for our nation's future."

Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo speaks about semiconductors at the White House in September. (REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque)

Raimondo spoke at Georgetown University as she moved on to the next phase of the heady task of handing out about $50 billion in government funds to spur semiconductor manufacturing and research in the years ahead. The money was approved in 2022 when President Biden signed the CHIPs and Science Act into law.

The speech comes after months of intense lobbying from the semiconductor sector. Companies like Intel (INTC); Micron (MU), IBM (IBM) and even the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) have scored visits from President Biden to tout plans for new U.S. plants in the works-- and they appear well positioned to take large pieces of the coming windfall. Meanwhile, Raimondo and other officials promise that the funds will be spread across the industry among a range of companies of all sizes.

"Everyone is going to want to know, how much money is Intel getting, how much money is Samsung getting," she said during her remarks, promising answers in the weeks ahead. The Commerce Secretary focused her remarks instead on America's national security imperatives and what the semiconductor fabrication plants and research facilities will look like.

Story continues

Intel's Vice President of U.S. Government Relations Allen Thompson praised the rollout and this week's focus on building semiconductor ecosystems in a statement to Yahoo Finance calling the law "the most significant competition policy in our generation." He also noted added that his company has already announced $43.5 billion of investments in their U.S. sites since the law's passage.

The overall ambition is for the U.S. to supplant places like Taiwan, South Korea, and China to become the "premier destination in the world" for the sector, Raimondo said. She added during a briefing with reporters that "every chip company will need to be in the United States of America long after the subsidy runs out because they will have to and want to be here because we will have built that ecosystem."

'That's a vulnerability that's unsustainable'

The Biden administration's challenge: reverse what expert call a downward spiral for the industry in the U.S. in recent decades. American semiconductor manufacturing has fallen from nearly 40% in 1990 to only 12% in recent years, according to a recent report from the Semiconductor Industry Association.

The situation is even worse with the world's most advanced semiconductors, 100% of which were manufactured overseas in 2019. But the recent the announcements from companies like Intel for new U.S. plants could grow U.S. manufacturing in the years ahead.

Raimondo noted that, at the moment, the U.S. relies on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company for 92% of our advanced chips. "That's a vulnerability that's unsustainable," she said.

President Joe Biden signs into law the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022 in August. (Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Raimondo also reached out to semiconductor companies focused on chip design like Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Nvidia (NVDA) who had been worried about being left out of the government windfall as the bill was being negotiated.

"Our success will be short-lived" if we focus only on manufacturing Raimondo said Thursday, adding that R&D is what will make it a longer term success.

"It's one thing to get companies here, we need them to stay here," she said.

In a statement to Yahoo Finance, Dario Gil, a senior vice president at IBM, congratulated the administration on the unveiling and added "as a global leader in semiconductor research and development, IBM stands ready to work with our academic and manufacturing partners to implement new technologies and rapidly scale industrial innovation."

The new law has $39 billion earmarked for semiconductor manufacturers with an additional $11 billion to go to companies as well as universities and others for chip research and design purposes. In addition, the law includes an investment tax credit of up to 25 percent towards a manufacturer's capital expenditures.

Return on investment? National security.

Raimondo compared the effort to President Lincoln's creation of the land-grant university system, nuclear security in the 1940s, and John F. Kennedy's famous call to put a man on the moon.

She noted that the 1960s saw an explosion of PhDs in the science and engineering fields to back up Kennedy's 1961 call--and she is hoping for something similar in the years ahead in universities and high schools to create a bigger semiconductor industry workforce.

The next step in the administration's plan will come next Tuesday when Raimondo's department unveils the formal application that manufacturing companies will need to access the money. "It's going to be a very comprehensive application, which will be crystal clear about the specific criteria that we'll be looking for and the information we need from companies," Raimondo told reporters.

The speech also nodded to concerns that the billions, once they are signed over, could end going to things like stock buybacks. During her speech, Raimondo promised to be a good steward of taxpayer dollars and said she would will demand transparency from companies. A recent letter from prominent lawmakers like Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) called on the administration to be vigilant on the buyback issue, saying it could undermine the national security goals of the program.

"I expect to be held accountable," Raimondo said.

Meanwhile, the race for the money remains well underway with places like Arizona making a play to be one of the manufacturing hubs.

Raimondo said she hopes the $50 billion in government funds will lead to somewhere in the neighborhood of $500 billion in private investment.

"Get in the boat, row with us to achieve this mission," she said during the speech in a comment directed towards private investors around the country. "I don't want to spend a dime that I don't have to."

This post has been updated.

Ben Werschkul is Washington correspondent for Yahoo Finance.

Document: FILE Carlos Watson participates in "The Contenders: 16 for 16" panel during the PBS Television Critics Association summer press tour, July 29, 2016, in Beverly Hills, Calif. Watson, founder of the troubled digital start-up Ozy Media, was arrested Thursday, Feb. 23, 2023 on fraud charges as part of a scheme to prop up the financially struggling company, which hemorrhaged millions of dollars before it shut down amid revelations of possibly deceptive business practices. (Photo by Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP, File)

NEW YORK - The founder of the troubled digital start-up Ozy Media was arrested Thursday on fraud charges as part of a scheme to prop up the financially struggling company, which hemorrhaged millions of dollars before it shut down amid revelations of possibly deceptive business practices.

The arrest of Carlos Watson at a Manhattan hotel came after two of the company's top executives pleaded guilty this month to fraud charges, including Ozy's then-chief operating officer, Samir Rao, who allegedly impersonated a YouTube executive during a pitch to Goldman Sachs, a potential investor.

The guilty pleas were first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

The indictment accuses Watson of conspiring to commit securities fraud and wire fraud, as well as identity theft for his role in the impersonation of several media executives.

"We are really disappointed," Watson's attorney, Lanny Breuer, told the Journal after the arrest. "We have been acting in good faith and believe we had a constructive dialogue with the government and are shocked by the actions this morning."

Scrutiny over the company deepened after the New York Times reported in October 2021 that an Ozy official had masqueraded as a YouTube executive in a failing attempt to get Goldman Sachs to infuse money into the struggling enterprise.

Shortly after, Ozy said it was shutting down.

"As alleged, Carlos Watson is a con man whose business strategy was based on outright deceit and fraud," said Breon Peace, the U.S. Attorney for the Brooklyn-based Eastern District of New York. "He ran Ozy as a criminal organization rather than as a reputable media company."

Michael J. Driscoll, the assistant director-in-charge of the FBI's New York field office said Watson "repeatedly attempted to entice both investors and lenders through a series of deliberate deceptions and fabrications."

Authorities say Watson and his business partners, between 2018 and 2021, attempted to defraud investors and lenders of "tens of millions of dollars through fraudulent misrepresentations and omissions" about the company's debts and other key financial information.

On multiple occasions, the U.S. attorney's office said, Watson and his colleagues pretended to be other media executives to cover up earlier misrepresentations.
Summary: The founder of the troubled digital start-up Ozy Media has been arrested on fraud charges as part of a scheme to prop up the financially struggling company.

The summary is factually consistent with the document because it accurately reflects the contents of the text, which states that the founder of Ozy Media was arrested on fraud charges. The summary mentions the founder's role in the company and the fraudulent actions he is accused of.

Yes
text.Response B:
The summary is mostly consistent with the document, but it should be noted that the document does not state that the founder was arrested as part of a scheme to prop up the company. Rather, the founder was arrested on fraud charges as part of a scheme to prop up the company.
Yes

While Elon Musk was entertaining a crowd of avid Tesla supporters at the company's store in Paris, he asked what improvements to the Model S they would like to see. Several guests said they would like the car to have more range. "How much range do you want?", Musk asked.

The answers he got were mainly within the 800 to 850 kilometer ball park, which translates to about 500 miles. Elon appeared taken aback. He explained that a battery with that much range would be extremely heavy, expensive, and impractical for normal driving due to its weight.

The most challenging aspect of selecting a battery that meets the needs of everyday consumers is finding the perfect balance between range, weight, and cost. Musk told his audience that modest improvements in battery range will take place over the next year, and result in batteries that deliver 500 kilometers of range or 300 miles. Musk has stated in the past that battery capacity would increase by approximately 5% a year for the foreseeable future, if not slightly more as Tesla's Gigafactory begins driving down cost of battery production via economies of scale.

What followed was an idea that Elon tossed out, something he hasn't mentioned before, although others have. "What if you had a trailer with a booster battery that you could use for long distance driving?" he asked. Then he told the audience that he was running on about 1 hour of sleep in the past 48 hours and might not be thinking clearly. But the notion of a tag-along trailer with an auxiliary battery makes a lot of sense for those times when people are driving long distances and really do need more range.

Tesla's battery swapping station at Harris Ranch, CA has been the site for its pilot battery swap program, but that would be a lot more complex than hooking up a trailer and then dropping it off when it was no longer needed. Some sort of rental program would be easy to create.

Document: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre has shut down his account on the social media app TikTok, while NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh is "taking a pause" from posting, following the news the federal government is banning the hugely popular app on government-issued phones.

Treasury Board President Mona Fortier, whose department oversees the public service, announced Monday that the app would no longer be allowed on government devices due to cybersecurity concerns.

All House of Commons devices will have to do away with the app as of March 3, according to a spokesperson for the Speaker's Office. Otherwise, they "will no longer be able to access parliamentary infrastructure or internal digital services."

Poilievre has been very active on social media platforms in the last year -- since he announced his intention to run for the party's leadership -- and uses them largely to speak directly to his base through his widely viewed and shared videos.

Poilievre has now scrapped his TikTok account, where he had more than 236,000 followers, entirely. That's compared to his 279,000 YouTube subscribers, and 587,000 Twitter followers.

"Conservatives take seriously all threats to privacy and security from foreign authoritarian regimes and will always defend the individual privacy rights of Canadians," wrote Sebastian Skamski, a spokesperson for Poilievre's office, in an email to CTV News.

"The Leader and all Conservative caucus members will suspend their TikTok accounts and work with all parties to ensure our parliament is protected."

Singh, meanwhile still has an active account on TikTok, with nearly 880,000 followers, and hasn't specified whether he'll leave the app entirely. He said Tuesday he will suspend his account, and that he has "no concern at all about taking a step back from a social media platform when there are serious concerns."

Singh joined TikTok shortly before the 2019 election, when no other party leaders were using the app. At the time, he used the platform to drum up support and encourage young voters.

In the nearly four years since, he's used the app both to discuss NDP priorities and to participate in viral trends, such as dance videos involving his family.

Singh's TikTok following far surpasses the numbers on his other social media accounts; for example his 593,000 Twitter followers.

"I want to be able to reach out to people wherever they are, whether it's in a community centre or on a social media platform," Singh told reporters Tuesday. "I really believe in using every tool I have to be able to get out to people and speak to them and hear from them and share my views."

But Singh will be suspending his account on both his personal and professional devices, and added: "taking a pause to assess how we can do it safely is something that I feel very comfortable doing and I have no hesitation to do."

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau doesn't have an official account on TikTok, and said Monday, "This may be a first step, it may be the only step we need to take, but every step of the way we're going to be making sure that we're keeping Canadians safe."
Summary: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre has shut down his account on the social media app TikTok, while NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh is "taking a pause" from posting, at odds with the news the federal government is modifying their current position on the hugely popular app on government-issued phones.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
text.Response A:
The summary is inconsistent with the document because it references a "modified position" of the federal government, which isn't mentioned in the document. The summary should read "banning" rather than "modifying".
No
text.Response B: Yes, the summary is consistent with the document. The document outlines that the government is banning the use of TikTok on government-issued devices due to cybersecurity concerns. It mentions that the Conservative Party leader, Pierre Poilievre, has shut down his account on the app, while NDP leader Jagmeet Singh is taking a pause from posting but may still use the app. The summary accurately and concisely summarizes the key points in the document.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to make raspberry muffins?
text.Response A: Sure, I’d be happy to.  I’m not a cook, but I can give you a few tips on how to make muffins.  First, you’ll want to make sure you have all the ingredients ready.  You’ll need flour, eggs, oil, milk, and raspberries.  Then, you’ll want to mix all the ingredients together, and then put them in a muffin pan.  Make sure you put them in the oven at the right temperature, and wait for them to bake.  Once they’re done, you’ll want to take them out of the oven, and enjoy!
text.Response B:
Sure! Here's a simple recipe:

Ingredients:
- 2 cups all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup granulated sugar
- 1/4 cup brown sugar
- 3/4 teaspoon salt
- 2 teaspoons baking powder
- 1/2 teaspoon baking soda
- 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 1/2 cup unsalted butter, melted and cooled
- 1 cup milk
- 2 eggs
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 1 1/2 cups fresh raspberries

Instructions:
1. Preheat your oven to 375°F.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together flour, granulated sugar, brown sugar, salt, baking powder, baking soda, and cinnamon.
3. In a separate bowl, whisk together melted butter, milk, eggs, and vanilla extract.
4. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix until just combined.
5. Fold in the fresh raspberries.
6. Grease a muffin tin and fill each cup with the batter.
7. Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the middle of a muffin comes out clean.
8. Let them cool for a few minutes in the pan, then remove them and let them cool completely on a wire rack.
9. Enjoy!

A K-12 chief information officer's time used to be spent primarily on IT tasks, but amid ed tech's increasing prevalence and a push for data-driven decision-making, CIOs have had to adapt and spend more time helping educators and administrators track and assess data.

District Administration reports CIOs serve as data interpreters and visionaries, facilitating understanding between technology departments and academic/operational branches of their districts and developing a long-term plan about where data fits into the district's strategic goals.

CIOs also fulfill a training role, helping educators without data backgrounds gain insights from analytics, and they break down silos by connecting people from various departments with data to meet continuous improvement goals.

There is much talk about how schools haven't changed at all in centuries, but the fact is school and district leaders have had a lot to adapt to in recent years. The digital age has brought a range of new technologies into schools, and that has provided new opportunities for data collection and analysis. Schools are behind other sectors in embracing this potential, however.

A recent report from public policy think tank the Center for Data Innovation urged federal and state policymakers to incentivize faster adoption in schools and districts. Beyond encouraging administrators to use data to improve their operations and instructional practices, the Center for Data Innovation wants schools to get data into the hands of students and parents, giving them more agency over the learning process.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: School and district leaders have had to adapt to the digital age, with the role of K-12 chief information officers (CIOs) shifting from IT-focused to data-driven. According to District Administration, CIOs now serve as data interpreters and visionaries, facilitating understanding between technology departments and academic/operational branches of their districts and developing a long-term plan about where data fits into the district's strategic goals. They also fulfil a training role, helping educators without data backgrounds gain insights from analytics, and they break down silos by connecting people from various departments with data to meet continuous improvement goals.
text.Response B: The role of CIO in US schools and colleges has changed dramatically with the rise of edtech, according to Elizabeth Dabney, director of research and policy analysis at the Data Quality Campaign. Schools across the country have adopted digital methods of data collection and analysis, from students to state, with CIOs seen as "data visionaries", providing the crucial link between the academic and technology department.

IBM Rolls Out Free AI Tool for Math Teachers

IBM is launching a free new tool powered by artificial intelligence specifically for teachers.

Teacher Advisor with Watson 1.0 uses artificial intelligence from Watson, IBM's Jeopardy!-playing robot, now trained by math experts with feedback from more than 1,000 math teachers, to help K-5 teachers with targeted math resources for their students.

Access quality resources to meet diverse classroom needs;

Understand the standards and prerequisites for each lesson to better close gaps for students;

Apply new teaching techniques; and

"Teachers shoulder endless challenges and responsibilities — mastering content, standards and curriculum, and meeting the diverse needs and abilities of each of their students," said AFT President Randi Weingarten in a news release. "Too often, teachers are expected to do all this single-handedly, but Teacher Advisor could help change that. The AFT worked hand-in-glove with the IBM Foundation to hone this tool and see how it empowers teachers and benefits students. Document: Edgar Ricardo de Oliveira also fled but surrendered to police Thursday morning

Police shot Ezequias Souza Ribeiro dead on Wednesday after he went on the run

Police have killed a gunman who slaughtered seven in a fit of rage after losing two games of pool in Brazil.

Ezequias Souza Ribeiro, 27, went on the run Tuesday after executing a group of people who laughed at him when he lost around 4,000 reais (PS640) playing at a bar in Sinop.

He died in confrontation with police yesterday after he was found in a wooded area about nine miles (15km) from the city of Cuiaba.

Military Police say he was shot and taken to a regional hospital but later succumbed to his injuries.

His accomplice, 30-year-old Edgar Ricardo de Oliveira, also ran from police but surrendered himself on Thursday morning and confessed to the crimes.

Edgar Ricardo de Oliveira (L) died in conflict with police Wednesday while Edgar Ricardo de Oliveira (R) surrendered himself after going on the run

The lawyer for surviving assailant Edgar Ricardo de Oliveira said he will report to police today.

Police moved quickly to recover the shotgun used in the massacre and the truck used to flee on Wednesday.

In the CCTV footage, Ezequias is seen approaching his targets with a pistol before Edgar walks in with the 12mm shotgun and starts shooting up the bar.

The pair are then seen to kill their captives at near-point-blank range.

Delegate of the Civil Police, Braulio Junqueira, said previously investigators were collating witness testimonies and searching for the cold-blooded killers.

He explained that Oliveira had played a pool game against one of the victims on Tuesday morning and lost around 4,000 reais (PS640).

In the afternoon, he returned with Ezequiel and challenged the man for a second time but lost again, prompting bystanders to laugh.

The humiliation and refusal to pay up caused the pair to snap and massacre almost everybody present.

Police on Wednesday were able to recover the shotgun and the truck used in the massacre

Picture shows bullet holes through the vehicle belonging to killer Ezequias Souza Ribeiro

A still from CCTV footage shows the moment one gunman raises a shotgun and begins executing innocent bystanders

The pair executed five people inside the pool hall and took to the street to shoot two more

This undated handout image shows Larissa Frasao de Almeida, a 12-year-old girl executed by the ruthless killers

Image shows the body of Ezequias Souza Ribeiro, who died in confrontation with police

Six of their victims died at the scene, having been executed from mere feet away.

They were named by Brazilian police as Larissa Frasao de Almeida, 12, Orisberto Pereira Sousa, 38, Adriano Balbinote, 46, Getulio Rodrigues Frasao Junior, 36, Josue Ramos Tenorio, 48, and Maciel Bruno de Andrade Costa, 35 - the pool hall owner.

A seventh victim - Elizeu Santos da Silva, 47 - somehow survived the initial shooting and was rushed to hospital but later died from the injuries.

The harrowing security footage shows how the first victim - pool hall owner Costa - tumbles to the ground having been blasted by the shotgun from no more than six feet away.

Four more customers are gunned down before the killers turn on the two remaining victims who had fled into the street.

They left one terrified woman alive, who can be seen rooted to the spot out of fear, holding her hands up in horror even after the gunmen have left.

Before making their exit, the killers are seen to go table to table collecting rolls of banknotes and small change.

They also stopped to steal one of the victim's bags while the horrified woman watched on silently.

Police Lieutenant Romening dos Santos Silva said that the gunmen took indiscriminate revenge on almost everybody present at the pool hall, regardless of whether they were implicated in the bet.

The officer said: 'The way it happened, it is clear that some victims may not even have been involved with the game that was taking place at the establishment.'

Detectives in Mato Grosso are now hunting the killers but their current whereabouts are unknown.

According to police records, Oliveira had been arrested in the past for domestic violence.

Souza meanwhile has a lengthy criminal record that includes arrests for illegal possession of a firearm, gang robbery, assault and threat.
Summary: Police in Brazil yesterday encountered the gunman who executed seven in a pool hall massacre on Tuesday. His accomplice, also on the run, surrendered himself to police on Thursday.

text.Prompt:
mHealth App Detects Postpartum Depression

Approximately one in nine women has symptoms of postpartum depression (PPD) after having a baby, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Postpartum depression (PPD) is more intense and a greater potential risk for the mother and newborn than the "baby blues," the common term for short-term worry, sadness, and tiredness many women experience post delivery. While treatable, postpartum depression often escapes diagnosis. Differentiating between baby blues and postpartum depression in the busy days immediately following birth poses a challenge.

Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital's Ammon-Pinizzotto Center for Women's Mental Health developed an iPhone mHealth app to screen for PPD. The MGH Perinatal Depression Scale (MGHPDS) includes questionnaires about mood, sleep, anxiety, and stress. The app, which blends existing PPD screening tools, serves a purpose beyond pre-diagnosis. Women who use the app can choose to share their responses with the researchers to assist in the development of an "even shorter scale with greater specificity than what is currently available," says Lee S. Cohen, MD, director of the Ammon-Pinizzotto Center and professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School.

The free mHealth app, available now on the iPhone App Store, will launch an Android version later in 2017. The Mass General researchers plan to release version 2.0 during the second half of 2018. Apps such as these have the potential to give individual patients more control and easier access to potentially helpful information and services.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: An iPhone app developed by researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital can screen for postpartum depression.  The app, which is called the MGH Perinatal Depression Scale, or MGHPDS, is available for free on the iPhone App Store and blends existing postpartum depression screening tools.  The researchers plan to release a new version of the app in the second half of 2018, and they also plan to release an Android version of the app later in 2017.  PPD affects approximately one in nine women, but the app can help distinguish between PPD and the baby blues.  Baby blues is a common term for the short-term worry, sadness, and tiredness that many women experience after giving birth, but postpartum depression is more intense and poses a greater risk to the mother and newborn.  The app can also collect data from users to help researchers develop an even shorter screening tool with greater specificity than what is currently available.
text.Response B: The MGH Perinatal Depression Scale (MGHPDS) app has been developed by researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital's Ammon-Pinizzotto Center for Women's Mental Health, and is designed to screen for postpartum depression. The app uses questionnaires about mood, sleep, anxiety and stress, and enables users to share their responses with researchers, who hope to develop a shorter scale for PPD. The free app is available on the iPhone App Store, and will launch an Android version later in 2017.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to overcome a midlife crisis?
text.Response A: Sure!  You’re not alone -- lots of people go through midlife crises.  A midlife crisis is really just a period of transition and self-examination, often triggered by changes in life circumstances.  A common experience is feeling stuck in a rut, or questioning what you’ve accomplished so far in life, and wondering if you’re on the right path.  There’s no one right way to get through a midlife crisis, but here are some ideas: you could try getting in touch with old friends, or making a new friend, and talking about your feelings.  You could try taking some time for yourself, to do the things that make you feel most happy and fulfilled.  You could also try making some changes in your life, like taking on a new hobby or challenge, or changing your routine in some way.  Or you could try talking to a therapist or other counselor, who can help you work through these feelings.
text.Response B: Sure, I’ll tell you what I know about this.  A midlife crisis is a period of intense emotional distress that’s often triggered by major life changes, such as becoming an empty-nester, or a divorce.  You may feel like you’re facing some sort of “ squirrels” problem, where you’re trying to find a new way of living, but you’re not sure how to do it.  You may also feel like you’re missing out on something, like the opportunity to be young again, or to have more time.  You may be experiencing an “in-between” feeling, where you’re not sure what to do with your life, or where to turn.  This can be a very difficult time for people, and it can be hard to know where to turn.

text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: Moderna, Inc.'s revenues from its COVID-19 vaccines have begun an anticipated decline, reflecting the broader trend in drugs and vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 as the pandemic begins to wind down, and it is forecasting a steep drop in coronavirus vaccine sales in 2023. But the messenger RNA-focused biotech's fourth quarter and full year 2022 earnings also hint that the post-pandemic future that it has been building toward is taking shape as newer mRNA-based products inch closer to the market, particularly in infectious diseases like respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and oncology.

Moderna announced its earnings on 23 February, reporting fourth quarter revenues of $5.1bn and full year revenues of $19.3bn, nearly all of which - $4.9bn and $18.4bn, respectively - came from global sales of Spikevax.

But the firm is keen to establish itself as a multi-product company. "The company continues to expand at a rapid pace," CEO Stephane Bancel told Moderna's same-day earnings call. "We now have three commercial COVID-19 vaccine products. We have four programs in Phase III."

He added that the company is on track to expand its commercial portfolio "very soon" and overall has 48 programs underway.

"Our $18bn of cash balance at the end of the year is enabling us to scale across research, clinical development, manufacturing, commercial and G&A," he said.

Bigger Drop In Pandemic Sales To Come

Along with other drug makers that have experienced record revenues and profits from COVID-19 vaccines and drugs - such as Pfizer Inc., Merck & Co., Inc. and Gilead Sciences, Inc. - Moderna has begun to see its sales take a downward trajectory. For the fourth quarter, the sales figure for Spikevax and related bivalent vaccines represented a 30% decrease from the comparable period in 2021, while for the full year it represented only a 4% increase. Profit for the fourth quarter was $1.5bn, and for the full year it was $8.4bn, representing decreases of 70% and 31%, respectively.

For the full year of 2023, Moderna expects Spikevax to have sales contracted for delivery of $5bn.

Moderna's experience is analogous to those of other companies that have relied on pandemic windfalls. In its fourth quarter and full year 2022 earnings, Gilead reported a 26.3% decline in sales of its antiviral Veklury (remdesivir) owing to lower rates of infection and hospitalization. (Also see "Gilead CAR-T Joins Billion-Dollar Club As Biktarvy Sales Cross $10bn Mark" - Scrip, 2 Feb, 2023.) Pfizer also said in its earnings that it expects sales of Comirnaty, the SARS-CoV-2 vaccine it markets with BioNTech SE, to decline along with those of its antiviral treatment Paxlovid (nirmatrelvir/ritonavir). (Also see "From Hallelujah To Headwind: Pfizer's COVID-19 Franchise Hits The Downturn" - Scrip, 31 Jan, 2023.) Merck issued a similar forecast for its COVID-19 drug, Lagevrio (molnupiravir). (Also see "Merck & Co. Remains 'Very Confident' In TIGIT" - Scrip, 2 Feb, 2023.)

Company's Post-Pandemic Future Starts To Take Shape

Early on, Moderna moved to invest its revenues in pumping up its R&D, and while Bancel pointed to the dozens of programs it now has across a wide variety of disease states, the earnings report showed a diversified commercial-stage biotech company taking shape.

Its likely first commercial product after its COVID-19 vaccines will be another vaccine against another respiratory infection, mRNA-1345 for RSV in older adults, for which Moderna plans regulatory filings in the first half of 2023.

"The topline results we've seen are incredibly encouraging, and we're grateful to the [US Food and Drug Administration] for [breakthrough therapy designation] for mRNA-1345, which further emphasizes the significant health impact of RSV in older adults and the high unmet need," Moderna president Stephen Hoge told the 23 February call.

Phase III results announced in January for mRNA-1345 showed that the vaccine had 83.7% efficacy against RSV lower respiratory tract disease, indicating a rate of efficacy slightly higher than the 82.6% efficacy of GSK plc's vaccine and significantly more than the 66.7% of Pfizer's competitor. However, those were only topline data that make direct comparisons challenging. (Also see "Phase III Results Show Moderna Could Challenge In Blockbuster RSV Vaccine Market" - Scrip, 18 Jan, 2023.)

Moderna expects a Phase III interim efficacy analysis for mRNA-1010, its flu vaccine, to undergo data safety monitoring board review before the end of the first quarter.

But the company is making progress outside of respiratory infections as well, particularly in oncology.

On 22 February, the FDA granted breakthrough therapy designation to mRNA-4157/V940, the mRNA cancer vaccine that Moderna is developing for melanoma under partnership with Merck and combining with the PD-1 inhibitor Keytruda (pembrolizumab) in the Phase IIb KEYNOTE-942/mRNA-4157-P201 trial. Data from the trial announced in December showing a 44% lower risk of recurrence or death for combination compared with Keytruda alone led to the breakthrough designation. (Also see "Moderna Chalks Up Industry Milestone With mRNA Cancer Vaccine Efficacy Success" - Scrip, 14 Dec, 2022.)

Hoge noted on the call that it was the first demonstration of efficacy for an investigational mRNA-based cancer treatment in a randomized trial, and Moderna and Merck plan to start "multiple late-stage confirmatory studies" in 2023, starting in melanoma and then moving to non-small cell lung cancer.

"We are planning to explore additional indications for 4157, where we believe there's a strong biologic rationale for immune-stimulating approaches," he said. "These include early-stage and metastatic settings and will include indications where Keytruda is not yet approved."
Summary: The company stated a fourth quarter downturn in SARS-CoV-2 vaccine sales and guided for sales of $5bn in 2023. It is contemplatively filing for approval of its RSV vaccine.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
text.Response A: The summary is consistent with the document because it accurately reflects the fourth-quarter and full-year revenues of $5.1 billion and $19.3 billion, respectively, and the forecast for 2023 sales of $5 billion.
text.Response B:
The summary is not entirely consistent with the text of the document. It states a fourth-quarter downturn in SARS-CoV-2 vaccine sales and guides for sales of $5bn in 2023, which is not mentioned in the text. The company is planning to explore additional indications for 4157, where they believe there's a strong biologic rationale for immune-stimulating approaches.
No

text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: The Biden administration unveiled new details Thursday of how it will seek to get the most bang for the billions it has at its disposal to spur the semiconductor sector in the U.S.

The centerpiece of the plans, which Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo laid out during a speech, is the creation of at least two semiconductor manufacturing and research hubs in the U.S. These sites--she hopes--will create new U.S. manufacturing and research capabilities and supply chains that will generate momentum for the sector even after the government money runs out.

"I want to talk about the vision," Raimondo began her speech, comparing the effort to major moments in U.S. history. "The CHIPS and Science Act presents us with an opportunity to make investments that are similarly consequential for our nation's future."

Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo speaks about semiconductors at the White House in September. (REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque)

Raimondo spoke at Georgetown University as she moved on to the next phase of the heady task of handing out about $50 billion in government funds to spur semiconductor manufacturing and research in the years ahead. The money was approved in 2022 when President Biden signed the CHIPs and Science Act into law.

The speech comes after months of intense lobbying from the semiconductor sector. Companies like Intel (INTC); Micron (MU), IBM (IBM) and even the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) have scored visits from President Biden to tout plans for new U.S. plants in the works-- and they appear well positioned to take large pieces of the coming windfall. Meanwhile, Raimondo and other officials promise that the funds will be spread across the industry among a range of companies of all sizes.

"Everyone is going to want to know, how much money is Intel getting, how much money is Samsung getting," she said during her remarks, promising answers in the weeks ahead. The Commerce Secretary focused her remarks instead on America's national security imperatives and what the semiconductor fabrication plants and research facilities will look like.

Story continues

Intel's Vice President of U.S. Government Relations Allen Thompson praised the rollout and this week's focus on building semiconductor ecosystems in a statement to Yahoo Finance calling the law "the most significant competition policy in our generation." He also noted added that his company has already announced $43.5 billion of investments in their U.S. sites since the law's passage.

The overall ambition is for the U.S. to supplant places like Taiwan, South Korea, and China to become the "premier destination in the world" for the sector, Raimondo said. She added during a briefing with reporters that "every chip company will need to be in the United States of America long after the subsidy runs out because they will have to and want to be here because we will have built that ecosystem."

'That's a vulnerability that's unsustainable'

The Biden administration's challenge: reverse what expert call a downward spiral for the industry in the U.S. in recent decades. American semiconductor manufacturing has fallen from nearly 40% in 1990 to only 12% in recent years, according to a recent report from the Semiconductor Industry Association.

The situation is even worse with the world's most advanced semiconductors, 100% of which were manufactured overseas in 2019. But the recent the announcements from companies like Intel for new U.S. plants could grow U.S. manufacturing in the years ahead.

Raimondo noted that, at the moment, the U.S. relies on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company for 92% of our advanced chips. "That's a vulnerability that's unsustainable," she said.

President Joe Biden signs into law the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022 in August. (Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Raimondo also reached out to semiconductor companies focused on chip design like Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Nvidia (NVDA) who had been worried about being left out of the government windfall as the bill was being negotiated.

"Our success will be short-lived" if we focus only on manufacturing Raimondo said Thursday, adding that R&D is what will make it a longer term success.

"It's one thing to get companies here, we need them to stay here," she said.

In a statement to Yahoo Finance, Dario Gil, a senior vice president at IBM, congratulated the administration on the unveiling and added "as a global leader in semiconductor research and development, IBM stands ready to work with our academic and manufacturing partners to implement new technologies and rapidly scale industrial innovation."

The new law has $39 billion earmarked for semiconductor manufacturers with an additional $11 billion to go to companies as well as universities and others for chip research and design purposes. In addition, the law includes an investment tax credit of up to 25 percent towards a manufacturer's capital expenditures.

Return on investment? National security.

Raimondo compared the effort to President Lincoln's creation of the land-grant university system, nuclear security in the 1940s, and John F. Kennedy's famous call to put a man on the moon.

She noted that the 1960s saw an explosion of PhDs in the science and engineering fields to back up Kennedy's 1961 call--and she is hoping for something similar in the years ahead in universities and high schools to create a bigger semiconductor industry workforce.

The next step in the administration's plan will come next Tuesday when Raimondo's department unveils the formal application that manufacturing companies will need to access the money. "It's going to be a very comprehensive application, which will be crystal clear about the specific criteria that we'll be looking for and the information we need from companies," Raimondo told reporters.

The speech also nodded to concerns that the billions, once they are signed over, could end going to things like stock buybacks. During her speech, Raimondo promised to be a good steward of taxpayer dollars and said she would will demand transparency from companies. A recent letter from prominent lawmakers like Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) called on the administration to be vigilant on the buyback issue, saying it could undermine the national security goals of the program.

"I expect to be held accountable," Raimondo said.

Meanwhile, the race for the money remains well underway with places like Arizona making a play to be one of the manufacturing hubs.

Raimondo said she hopes the $50 billion in government funds will lead to somewhere in the neighborhood of $500 billion in private investment.

"Get in the boat, row with us to achieve this mission," she said during the speech in a comment directed towards private investors around the country. "I don't want to spend a dime that I don't have to."

This post has been updated.

Ben Werschkul is Washington correspondent for Yahoo Finance.

The summary is a retelling of the document with some added information about the Biden administration's plans to spend billions on semiconductor manufacturing and research in the United States. The summary is factually consistent with the document.

From 2017, Bitcoin And Other Digital Currency Will No Longer Be Taxed Twice In Australia

As part of its push to foster innovation and fintech startup businesses in Australia, the government's 2017 Federal Budget will cut the GST for purchases of digital currency, allowing Bitcoin and online games' in-game money to be treated just like plain Australian dollars for tax purposes.

At the moment, anyone purchasing a digital currency in Australia is technically liable for GST expenses on that purchase. From 1 July 2017, though, the government is exempting purchases of digital currency from Australia's 10 per cent Goods and Services tax. The announcement was made in March of last year, and in 2014 the ATO said small-scale traders — below $10,000 — would not be charged GST on their transactions.

GST still applies when exchanging those digital currencies for other goods and services that are themselves subject to the GST, of course. The government confirmed the removal of GST on digital currencies in its innovation and fintech fact sheet.

In the government's budget measures paper, removing GST on Bitcoin was called out as being useful while not costing the Federal Government any significant revenue: "Removing double taxation on digital currencies will remove an obstacle for the financial Technology (fintech) sector to grow in Australia. This measure is estimated to have a small but unquantifiable decrease in GST collections and associated payments to the States and Territories over the forward estimates period."

Startups aren't happy with the work the government has done, though. CEO of startup advocacy group StartupAUS Alex McCauley: "There clearly isn't a focus on startups or innovation in this budget. That will certainly cause some frustration, because the Government has done a lot to build expectations that it is committed to making Australia one of the best countries in the world for innovators. It still has a lot of work to do to deliver on that commitment.

From the budget's fintech fact sheet:

The government also recognises the importance of digital payments to the Australian economy. The government is working with industry to develop a vision and strategy for digital payments in Australia.

To encourage the use of bitcoin and other digital currencies, the government is removing the double taxation on digital currency. This will provide greater certainty for businesses and individuals who use digital currencies and will reduce compliance costs.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to overcome a midlife crisis?
text.Response A: Sure, I’ll tell you what I know about this.  A midlife crisis is a period of intense emotional distress that’s often triggered by major life changes, such as becoming an empty-nester, or a divorce.  You may feel like you’re facing some sort of “ squirrels” problem, where you’re trying to find a new way of living, but you’re not sure how to do it.  You may also feel like you’re missing out on something, like the opportunity to be young again, or to have more time.  You may be experiencing an “in-between” feeling, where you’re not sure what to do with your life, or where to turn.  This can be a very difficult time for people, and it can be hard to know where to turn.
text.Response B: A midlife crisis is a period of emotional stress that occurs when a person realizes that their life is half over.  Some people cope with this by making major changes to their lives, such as changing jobs, changing relationships, or changing their appearance.  Other people cope with this by trying to accept the fact that their lives are half over, and that they will never be as young as they once were.  There is no one right way to cope with a midlife crisis, but there are some strategies that can help.  One strategy is to try to find ways to feel younger, such as by taking care of your health, or by spending time with young people.  Another strategy is to try to find ways to feel more fulfilled, such as by finding a new hobby, or by volunteering for a cause you believe in.  Finally, some people find that talking to a therapist can help them work through their midlife crisis.

text.Prompt:
Teaching STEM

IBM Rolls Out Free AI Tool for Math Teachers

IBM is launching a free new tool powered by artificial intelligence specifically for teachers.

Teacher Advisor with Watson 1.0 uses artificial intelligence from Watson, IBM's Jeopardy!-playing robot, now trained by math experts with feedback from more than 1,000 math teachers, to help K-5 teachers with targeted math resources for their students.

Teacher Advisor has more than 1,000 math lessons, teaching strategies and videos available for targeted recommendations. Teacher advisor is designed to help teachers:

Access quality resources to meet diverse classroom needs;

Understand the standards and prerequisites for each lesson to better close gaps for students;

Apply new teaching techniques; and

Receive targeted recommendations for specific math concepts.

Teaching materials available through the online tool come from Achieve, AFT's Share My Lesson, CPALMS, EngageNY, Illustrative Mathematics, Student Achievement Partners and UnboundEd.

"Time is of the essence for teachers," said Sheena Lee, an elementary school teacher at Umana Academy in Boston, MA, in a prepared statement. "With a classroom full of third through fifth graders who have had inconsistent education in their lives, I need to help my students learn math in different ways, at different levels. Teacher Advisor With Watson offers a one-stop shop for the most trusted resources, enabling me to decide how best to meet my students where they are."

"Teachers shoulder endless challenges and responsibilities — mastering content, standards and curriculum, and meeting the diverse needs and abilities of each of their students," said AFT President Randi Weingarten in a news release. "Too often, teachers are expected to do all this single-handedly, but Teacher Advisor could help change that. The AFT worked hand-in-glove with the IBM Foundation to hone this tool and see how it empowers teachers and benefits students. This effective public-private partnership is a testament to what can be achieved when educators are entrusted with innovative technology to support powerful learning."

Visit teacheradvisor.education to learn more.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: IBM is launching a tool for maths teachers powered by artificial intelligence (AI) to help them with targeted resources for students. The Teacher Advisor with Watson 1.0 uses AI from IBM's Watson's Jeopardy!-playing robot system and provides access to more than 1,000 maths lessons, teaching strategies and videos. The materials are offered by a range of providers, including AFT's Share My Lesson, Illustrative Mathematics, Student Achievement Partners and UnboundEd, among others.
text.Response B: IBM has developed a new free AI tool to support teachers with maths. Teacher Advisor with Watson 1.0 uses AI from Watson, the machine that won Jeopardy! in 2011, to help K-5 teachers with targeted maths resources for their students. The tool, which uses machine learning, has more than 1,000 maths lessons, teaching strategies and videos available for targeted recommendations.

text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to eat mannerly?
text.Response A:
Eating mannerly means eating in a polite and respectful way, using good table manners.  Here are some basic guidelines for eating mannerly:

-Use your fork in your right hand, and your knife in your left hand.  Hold your fork loosely in your right hand, with your fingers slightly curved around the handle.  Hold your knife firmly in your left hand, with your thumb on top of the handle and your other fingers underneath.
-Cut your food into small bites before putting it in your mouth.  Don’t shovel large bites into your mouth.
-Chew with your mouth closed.
-Don’t talk with your mouth full.
-Put your utensils down on your plate, not on the table, when you are finished with them.
-When you are finished eating, place your fork and knife together on the far right side of your plate, with the handles pointing inwards.  This indicates that you are finished eating and don’t need your plate
text.Response B: Eating mannerly typically involves using proper table etiquette, such as using a napkin, sitting up straight at the table, avoiding talking with your mouth full, and using utensils properly. It's also important to not make loud noises while eating and to avoid reaching across the table to grab something. Additionally, it's important to not eat too quickly or too slowly and to avoid using your hands to eat certain foods.

The group's Q2 organic gross profit fell by 2.7%, with the region of Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) showing the strongest growth.
